Aquaporin plays an important role in mediating chloroplastic CO2 concentration under high‐N supply in rice (Oryza sativa) plants
items.abstract: <jats:p>Our previous studies demonstrated that chloroplastic <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:styled-content> concentration (Cc) is not sufficient under high‐nitrogen (N) supply in rice plants. In this research, we studied how aquaporins‐ (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">AQPs</jats:styled-content>) mediated Cc under different N‐supply levels. A hydroponic experiment was conducted in a greenhouse with three different N levels (low N, 0.71 <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">m<jats:italic>M</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>; intermediate N, 2.86 <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">m<jats:italic>M</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>; and high N, 7.14 <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">m<jats:italic>M</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>) in a rice cultivar (<jats:italic>Oryza sativa</jats:italic> cv. Shanyou 63) and with an <jats:italic>ospip1;1</jats:italic> mutant (<jats:italic>Oryza sativa</jats:italic> cv. Nipponbare). The photosynthetic nitrogen‐use efficiency (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PNUE</jats:styled-content>) decreased with increasing leaf‐N content. Under high‐N supply, the estimated Cc was significantly lower than the theoretical Cc and the specific Rubisco activity (carboxylation efficiency/Rubisco content, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CE</jats:styled-content>/Rubisco) decreased, because of a decrease of relative <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:styled-content> diffusion conductance (total <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:styled-content> diffusion conductance/leaf‐N content, g<jats:sub>t</jats:sub>/N) in mesophyll cells. Real Time Quantitative PCR (Q‐RT‐PCR) showed that most <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">OsPIP1s</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> and <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">OsPIP2s</jats:styled-content></jats:italic> expression were downregulated under the high‐N supply. Furthermore, Cc and g<jats:sub>m</jats:sub> decreased in the <jats:italic>ospip1;1</jats:italic> mutant line compared with that of the wild‐type plant. It was concluded that under high‐N supply, the decreased <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PNUE</jats:styled-content> was associated with non‐sufficient Cc, mediated by <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">AQP</jats:styled-content> in mesophyll conductance.</jats:p>

Numerical modeling of cold magmatic CO<sub>2</sub> flux measurements for the exploration of hidden geothermal systems
container-title: Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The most accepted conceptual model to explain surface degassing of cold magmatic CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> in volcanic‐geothermal systems involves the presence of a gas reservoir. In this study, numerical simulations using the TOUGH2‐ECO2N V2.0 package are performed to get quantitative insights into how cold CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> soil flux measurements are related to reservoir and fluid properties. Although the modeling is based on flux data measured at a specific geothermal site, the Acoculco caldera (Mexico), some general insights have been gained. Both the CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> fluxes at the surface and the depth at which CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> exsolves are highly sensitive to the dissolved CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> content of the deep fluid. If CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> mainly exsolves above the reservoir within a fracture zone, the surface CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> fluxes are not sensitive to the reservoir size but depend on the CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> dissolved content and the rock permeability. For gas exsolution below the top of the reservoir, surface CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> fluxes also depend on the gas saturation of the deep fluid as well as the reservoir size. The absence of thermal anomalies at the surface is mainly a consequence of the low enthalpy of CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>. The heat carried by CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> is efficiently cooled down by heat conduction and to a certain extent by isoenthalpic volume expansion depending on the temperature gradient. Thermal anomalies occur at higher CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> fluxes (>37,000 g m<jats:sup>−2</jats:sup> d<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>) when the heat flux of the rising CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> is not balanced anymore. Finally, specific results are obtained for the Acoculco area (reservoir depth, CO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> dissolved content, and gas saturation state).</jats:p>
